Chance of dem control of House and Senate 15 > 47. Based on my forecast of the Perdue-Ossoff runoff election:
Prior to the election in November, fivethirtyeight's model had Ossoff leading 49.5 to 48.9 percent (0.6) in their polls based forecast and realclearpolitics gave Ossoff a 0.7 [1], |2] lead. In the end the result was 47.9-49.7 (-1.8). Thus the polls were off by 2.4 or 2.5 to Perdue's advantage.
At the moment fivethirtyeight has Ossoff ahead 49.2-47.4 (1.8) [3] and realclearpolitics 49.3 - 48.5 (0.8) [4]
Assuming the same polling error Perdue would be leading with up to 0.7 points. According to Nate Silver [5] many of the better pollster are not polling in Georgia for the runoff, decreasing the quality of the polls.
For comparison the polls in the special election are Warnock - Loeffler 49.8-48.0 (realclearpolitics [6]) and 49.5-47.2 (fivethirtyeight [3]) - a democratic lead of 1.8 or 2.2. I put this as a small Loeffler advantage based on the same polling error of 2.4-2.5. I can't reliably quantify other relevant factors such as the fraud allegations, how a runoff might draw more Republicans, the fact that control of the Senate is at stake and assume that these are captured by the polls. I did a lot of heavy math on this one today because I have been hoping that I am not very wrong and I wanted to make sure I was being objective here. The results swayed me a bit. I am basing the following off the Presidential election, even though I know some of the voters likely did not vote along party lines for the Senate. I did compare the total numbers of votes for each party, and they were fairly close to the presidential election numbers, with some votes going to 3rd party candidates which likely makes up the difference, so I am assuming the results for the runoff will be closer to the results for the Presidential election in a 50/50 race. Here is what I found: Democrats will have ˜90,000 new registered voters who will reach voting age between 3 November and 5 Jan, and many have registered for mail in ballots (Republicans will have new voters as well, so this may be moot). ˜1,200,000 absentee ballots requested. ˜1,600,000 million requested during 3 Nov election. ˜1,300,000 mail in ballots returned during 3 Nov elections, 65% of which were for Biden ˜845,000 Dem – ˜455,000 Rep. (This accounts for ˜81.5% of the requested mail in ballots being returned). Democrats received ˜400,000 more absentee ballot votes than Republicans in Nov 3 election.  ˜250,000 ballots already returned for runoff elections. Bernard Fraga, an Emory University professor who studies voting, said it’s possible that mail-in ballots, if anything, will be even more favorable for Democrats in the runoff because of attacks on the integrity of mail-in voting by President Donald Trump and many Georgia Republicans. However, it can reasonably be expected that at least 65% are for Democrats, which would be ˜162,500 Dem – ˜87,500 Rep.  If no additional mail in ballots are requested (they can be requested until 1 Jan), and approximately the same amount of ballots are returned, we can reasonably expect to see similar numbers in the runoffs, with ˜65% of the returned ballots voting for Democrats. Similar numbers of mail in ballots returned, if at 81.5% of those requested, would be ˜978,000 out of the current ˜1,200,000. This would mean that ˜635,000 would be for Dems and ˜342,000 for Reps. More than half of the record 5 million votes in the Nov. 3 general election were cast during its three-week early voting period. The final vote count was 2,461,854 Rep - 2,473,633 Dem Rep in-person vote 2,461,854-˜455,000 (mail in)= ˜2,006,854.  Dem in-person vote 2,473,633-˜845,000 (mail in)= ˜1,628,633  Out of the total ˜3,635,847 total in-person votes, ˜55% were Rep votes, and ˜45% were Dem votes. Early in-person voting could be even more important in the Jan. 5 runoffs because of the short period for voters to request and return ballots by mail. The first two days seem to be slower than the elections on 3 November, but still a record turnout for a runoff. It is reasonable to assume that more Democrats will vote in-person during the runoffs, not only due to the short timeline for requesting and returning ballots, but also to ensure that their votes count if there is any litigation over mail in ballots in the future, so it is slightly possible that the in-person voting could be more of a 50/50 split instead of the ˜55/45 seen on 3 Nov if the Reps have a similar split between mail in and in-person. IF this is not the case, and less Reps vote by mail, then the election results depend greatly on how many Republicans show up to vote in-person to mitigate the potential increase in percentage of Dems voting in-person and any increase in mail in votes that go the Dems way. I believe that many voters will show up for both sides, as a win for the Democrats would mean full control over the Executive branch, and Republicans want to stop that. However, the turnout will not be as good as the November election, as seen already. Also, with the President still saying that the elections were rife with fraud, and still tweeting that the Governor of Georgia should open a special session to verify signatures on ballots in an attempt to overturn the 3 November results, it could affect Republican turnout. According to multiple sources, “The president’s repeated attacks on election integrity could have undermining effects on efforts to mobilize Republican voters for the Jan. 5 runoffs.” President Trump tweeted this today: ““What a fool Governor @BrianKempGA of Georgia is. Could have been so easy, but now we have to do it the hard way,” Trump said on Twitter early Monday morning. “Demand this clown call a Special Session and open up signature verification, NOW. Otherwise, could be a bad day for two GREAT Senators on January 5th.” A lot of Rep voters believe the election is already decided, as the Dominion voting machines are flawed, and there is no sense in voting in an election where the winner is already decided. Will they still show up? Likely not in full force, but many will in case there is litigation to void the mail in results or hopes that the state conducts a hand count. Tweets coming from the current President, such as the one above, only work to cement that belief in those that truly believe that the election results were not accurate, and serves to reduce any potential that some of these voters would turn out anyway despite that belief. However, turnout on the Dem side will also be lower due to the belief that one does not need to vote because the rest of the voters will do their part and ensure the Dems win. There are also groups that believe boycotting the election is the way to go. While this is not the majority, even losing some of the Republican votes in Georgia to boycotting could put the election in the favor of the Democrats, with such a small margin to work with. If the mail in voting goes the same as the last election, the Republicans will need a 66% margin in in-person voting to counter the 65% margin Dems could have from mail in votes. With the polls indicating that both Democratic candidates are now narrowly favored to win, and a combination of lower turnout and potentially increased Democratic in-person voting, it is hard to say that the Democrats will not take both runoffs. However, if you go by odds alone, there is a 25% chance the Democrats will win both, and a 75% chance the Republicans will win just one. The only possible outcome at this point is either Democratic or Republican control of the Senate because the Democrats won the House already. Thus, the remaining two special senate races in Georgia are the determinants of this issue as the current balance in the senate will be 46(D) - 50 (R) - 2 (I) [Note the I's caucus with Democrats). The presidential election showed local races still favor the GOP in historically GOP areas (for example Maine), but that the President underperformed local candidates in many areas except when a large Latino population was present (Maine, Georgia). Presidential elections also see higher turnout which generally favors republicans.  Loeffler is an unpopular candidate and may lose her reelection (or is it still reelection if you were never elected in the first place?), but Purdue seems unlikely to lose as an incumbent. Further, given that Perdue's failure to secure 50% of the vote in the previous election seems to have been due to a Libertarian candidate (Shane Hazel) and his challenger his fairly socially progressive with respect to Georgia at large. Nevertheless, polls show both senate races in a dead heat (with Perdue slightly ahead of Ossoff and Loeffler tied or slightly behind Warnock), but given that polls have been slightly biased against republicans and democrats have to flip both seats to gain the senate this seems unlikely. I would estimate that the base rate odds of a dead heat race for both are 50-50, but given that Republicans only need one win that is a 25% - 75% ratio for R-D. Factoring in the lower turnout from an off-cycle election, the unpopularity of Loeffler, and the incumbency of Perdue I would estimate the most likely outcome is a Perdue victory and a Warnock victory splitting the Senate 47(D)-51(R)-2(I). The likelihood that democrats unseat Perdue and Loeffler seems low.  (15%)

Assume first that Democrats end the election with 48 and Republicans with 50, with two run-offs in Georgia, as seems likely. Democrats need to win both run-offs to control the Senate. If these were independent coin tosses, we'd have 25%/75% split on Dem vs Rep control of the Senate. Although Biden looks set to win Georgia, it's traditionally a Republican state and the Democrats have underperformed in the House and Senate elections relative to polls by a larger margin Biden has, suggesting some Biden votes are anti-Trump rather than pro-Dem. Georgia hasn't had a Dem senator since 2005. So the races aren't coin tosses. Pre-election, 538 had Ossoff (D) at 3/18 = 17% to beat Perdue (R), conditional on going to a run-off but Warnock (D) at 63% to beat Loeffler or Collins - this might not translate straightforwardly into 63% chance of Warnock beating Loeffler in the run-off though. Dems performed worse than 538 predicted. Say 15% chance of Ossoff (O) winning, 55% chance of Warnock (W) winning. They're plausibly correlated though, so we'd underestimate the chance of Dems winning both if we simply multiply P(O&W) = P(O)*P(W) = 0.15*0.5 = 0.075. Note that P(O&W) = P(O) + P(W) - P(O or W). P(O or W) is probs not much more than 0.5, say 0.53. Then P(O&W) = 0.15 + 0.5 - 0.53 = 0.12. There's some chance of Dems picking up a seat in NC or AK, so 12% is slightly too low. Update to 13%. This feels roughly reasonable for now.

For this forecast I will assume that Senate Elections held in a Presidential Election (e.g. 2020) are of a different nature to those held in Mid-Terms (2014). In addition I will assume that Republicans have no chance of retaking the House of Representatives, leaving only the Senate to compete for ->
https://projects.economist.com/us-2020-forecast/house In 2020, the Class II of the US Senate is up for election ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classes_of_United_States_senators#Class_2 Looking at previous Post WWII Presidential Election years where Class II has been up for election (2008, 1996, 1984, 1976, 1960, 1948) we see that they can be divided into two scenarios ->
Scenario 1 (1996, 1984, 1976, 1960) - Only 1/2 Senate seats changed parties with the seats always going to the party which lost the Presidential Election of that year.
Scenario 2 (2008, 1948) - Democrats gained 8/9 Senate seats with a Democrat winning the Presidency in both Election years. With Republicans currently at 53 seats and Democrats 47 seats, with Scenario 1 regardless of who wins the Presidency occurs Republicans win, if Scenario 2 occurs Democrats win ->
Democrats don't take Senate = 67% = 4/6 = Scenario 1
Democrats take Senate = 33% = 2/6 = Scenario 2 My personal intuition combined with the present predictions is that 2020 will be more Scenario 2 than 1 ->

First, we know that competition for control of both houses is competitive. Neither party, on base rates, is extremely likely to have a majority in either house. We can estimate the probability that a party wins both houses as a conjunction of the probability that they win each house. Additionally, we can look at the current breakdown of party affiliation in each house as relevant knowledge since we know that incumbents have a large advantage in winning elections, so each house is slightly more likely to remain controlled by the current majority party than it is to flip. I assign a higher probability to Dems having House and Reps winning senate than either winning the other for this reason. If Republicans control the house somehow, it would through into doubt my claim that Democrats should currently be more popular, which would mean that a Democratic victory in the Senate is even less likely than it was.

Let's put politics aside. Let's just look at the numbers.
Using the House first, and data from the website 270towin.com (https://www.270towin.com/2020-house-election/), we see that 43% of the seats are safe for the Democrats, and 36% for the Republicans; safe meaning districts that are demographically, economically, and are otherwise politically secure bastions for that party. We also see that 9% of the seats in the House are not safe, but lean towards or likely will go to the Democrats, while 8% lean towards the Republicans. That leaves a total of 5% of the seats in the house that could go either way. Barring some kind of tectonic demographic shift, there is just not enough at play in this election to see the Republicans taking back the House. The Republicans would have to win all of the seats that could go either way (5%) plus over half of the seats that lean towards the Democrats (5%), plus not lose any of the unsafe seats. A tall order for the party with an unpopular president. The Senate paints a slightly different story. Using data from the same website (https://www.270towin.com/2020-senate-election/), and only looking at the seats that are up for election, we see that 7% of the Senate seats are safe for the Democrats, and 10% are safe for Republicans, 5% lean Democrat, 7% lean Republican, but 6% of the seats could go either way...and those are all currently held by Republicans. Given that the Republican majority in the Senate is razor-thin (53%), winning the tossup seats and not losing any leaning seats gives the Democrats a slightly easier chance of winning back the Senate...but only just.

The way we view polling reminds me of the way we see the stock market... when we're up, we think we'll stay up; when we're down, we think we'll stay down. After all, I don't know how diverse we are (the GJO community.) It takes a pretty specific personality to become a forecasting hobbyist. So, I wonder how much that collectively colors the way we see the world.

3) I assume (based on my reading of news, polls etc) that there is nearly zero chance that Republicans can win the House.  I also assume the fact that Biden is winning in the presidential polls currently means there will be some tendency towards higher Democratic turnout in senate voting.
4) My base rate is betfair betting market which seems to currently give the Dems a 35-40 percent chance of winning a majority in both houses.  However, again I am assuming here that “control” by Dems could be 50/50 with a Dem VP elected.  For purposes of this question, I give Dems roughly a 65% chance to elect the President VP (which is a bit higher now than, but consistent with, betting markets).
5) I am also aware of a recent prediction of a FiveThirtyEight analyst that the “base case” right now is 51+ Dem senators.  So if I average that with the (say) 40% chance as implied by betting markets(which I adjust upwards to 42% based on my own evaluation), I get say 47.5-50% chance of Dem’s having 51+ senators.
6) I don’t have a clear sense of what are the chances of exactly 50 senators each, but betting markets seem to imply about a 15-20% chance.  Also, I see from Google search that currently, the only independents in the Senate caucus with the Dems, so I am making a simplifying assumption that such independents who caucus with one party can effectively be considered part of that party (ie part of its "control").  I also notice the question doesn't seem to allow the possibility of neither party controlling a branch - so I will make no offsetting adjustment for such possibility.
7) My calculation based on the above gives very close to 60% chance of Dems controlling both houses (ie my choice of 60% is not a rounding to nearest 5 or 10 percent).

Trying not to get tunnel vision here but the electoral reality is hard to ignore. A generous assessment puts the number of competitive House seats at 66 which sounds promising for Republicans considering they only have to flip 14 seats to win a majority. In practice, however this will prove very difficult. Of the districts up for grabs, only 3 are districts predicted to flip from one party to another and all of them favor Democrats. [1] Let’s look briefly at how this fits into a historical framework Since 1855, only 6 out of 19 (32%) of House majorities have lasted two years. The only two-year majorities to occur in the modern era occurred in 1947-1949 and 1955-1957. Democrats regained control of the House in 1949 after renewed Cold War fears overshadowed then-President Truman’s unpopular economic policies. [2] A recession saw Democrats end a two-year Republican majority as Cold War fears again flared up in the Middle East. [3] This marked the beginning of a 40-year majority. [4] Since the end of that extended period, the average majority has lasted 6.5 years including the current Congress. All things considered, the House is pretty much a lock for Democrats.  Conversely, the Republicans can take heart in the fact that they confront a more favourable Senate picture. It is not without its challenges, however. Gubernatorial appointee Martha McSally faces here first time on the ballot as Senator in a state that has been ravaged by the coronavirus, with many voters laying the blame at the feet of the GOP. Democrat Mark Kelly has a strong lead in the southwestern state. [5] Republicans face fights of varying degrees in five other states including Colorado, where former Governor Mark Hickenlooper leads handsomely. Even with two seats likely trophies for the Democrats, it probably won’t be enough to overturn the four seat deficit necessary to control both chambers. The House race, as it stands, is not very contentious. The Republicans would need to win not only their projected safe, likely, and leaning seats, but also all toss-ups and Dem-leaning seats as well as 11 of the 25 seats currently projected as "likely" for the Democrats just to tie. So I put it at about a 95% chance the Democrats keep the House.
The senate is much more interesting. In recent years, no party has kept the Senate for more than 4 years, with Republicans keeping it on average for 2.67 terms. Over the past 30 elections, the Senate has only flipped five times, but each of those flips has come in the past 16 cycles, meaning the chance of a flip is around 30% in the modern era. However, there have only been six elections in the past 30 years where a swing of more than four seats in either direction ended up changing the majority party, and large swings have become less frequent in recent years. Moreover, recent polling shows Republicans hold more "safe" and "likely" seats than Democrats, meaning Dems would have to win around 80% of the toss-up/leaning seats to gain the majority without the VP. However, polling has been trending consistently in favor of the Democrats in recent months, meaning that possibility is not negligible. So I give them a 30% chance of winning the Senate in November.

The Republicans have no coherent, unifying strategy. President Trump has started drawing rebukes from incumbent Republicans seeking to distance themselves from him while loyalists are now confronting the problem of his record on coronavirus and Civil Rights protest response. Trump has attempted to divert attention from his coronavirus failings by focusing on quelling Civil Rights protests. This is increasingly backfiring as people realize Trump's calls for law and order come under his administration's failure to maintain law and order.
Consequently, it is unlikely that Republicans will retake the gerrymandered House of Representatives by picking up any marginal districts that were lost in 2018. The possibility of Trump's strategy working is most likely to be found in Republicans retaining Senate seats in "red states." 
The question of how the votes play-out will depend largely on Joe Biden's actions. Thus far, Biden's strategy has been to let Trump be Trump; and this has led to a legitimate lead for Biden in national polls and apparent leads in state polls across "battleground states" and even in to Florida, Texas, and Arizona. If Biden can continue to sail the vast middle channel of the political spectrum with non-controversial policies and a non-controversial pick for vice president, Trump will have to generate momentum internally, and this is something that he has thus far been unable to do in 2020. On the other hand, if Biden has a series of gaffes or controversial policy proposals, these may not sink his chances to be president, but they may tilt Senate races against him and preserve the majority for Republicans. Given Biden's discipline thus far, I rate this as a 1-in-3 chance, with some of the likelihood that red seats will remain red (Graham remaining Senator in South Carolina, for example) subsumed.

The House is a lock for Democrats. So Senate control is the real question. Currently, polls (RealClearPolitics/fivethirtyeight) suggest that 46 Senate seats are safe/lean Democratic. 48 Senate seats are safe/lean Republican. That leaves 6 toss up states. So for Republicans to maintain control of the Senate they need either (i) 2 Senate seats from the 6 toss ups AND the Vice Presidency (Trump re-election), OR (ii) 3 Senate seats from the 6 toss ups (and Trump doesn't have to be re-elected). For Democrats to gain control of the Senate they need either (i) 4 Senate seats from the 6 toss ups AND the Vice Presidency (Biden election), OR (ii) 5 Senate seats from the 6 toss ups (and Biden doesn't have to be elected). Given the pandemic, tanking economy, and Trumps corresponding declines in the polls in key swing states (Fla, NC, Mich, etc) I currently give Joe Biden a 75% chance of taking the White House (historically re-election is tied to how the economy is performing at the time of election, and there's record levels of unemployment). When it comes to the 6 toss-up Senate seats (CO, IA, ME, NC, MI, and MT)...I have 4 of them leaning Democratic (my assigned probabilities, given current polls, are CO-D at 95% probability, ME-D at 62% probability, MI-D at 70% probability, and MT-D at 52% probability), with IA and NC being toss-ups (my assigned probabilities, given current polls at 50%-50%). With those assigned probabilities that gives Democrats about a 63% probability of winning 4 of those 6 toss ups. This 63% plus my assigned 75% probability of a Biden victory (meaning a Democratic VP will break ties in the Senate) should then impel me to increase the probability of Democrats taking control of both House and Senate to about 69%. But I've made this a little bit more conservative given two factors: (i) we're still over 4.5 months away from the election (and in a very volatile political/economic moment), and (ii) the Senate doesn't typically change control that often and even usually has a slight Republican/rural bias. So I brought down this 69% to a 63% probability that Demcrats take the House AND the Senate, with the remaining 37% that Democrats retain the House and Republicans retain the Senate.

I believe this fall's election will most likely result in a continuation of the current power dynamics in Congress with Democrats controlling the House and Republicans the Senate.  Prior to the emergence of COVID-19 I believe Republicans were well poised to retake control of the House and would most likely have retained control over the Senate. However, because of the COVID-19 outbreak, it's economic impacts and the likelihood of another spike in cases in the fall I believe Republicans will struggled to retake what they otherwise had strong chances of doing.
The swing districts Republicans need to retake the House in 2020 are predominately suburban districts, filled with voters who are typically skeptical at best of Trump and Republican rhetoric. These people are often drawn to Republican's economic  and tax platforms and are driven away from Democrats by cultural sentiments against liberalism and a generous welfare state. 
I believe it is most likely that Republican rhetoric on coronavirus and the economic conditions that will most likely exist in Nov. 2020 will compel voters in swing districts to retain their recently elected "opposition" representatives. These are citizens who already voted to install "opposition" politicians when economic conditions were good, and it seems highly unlikely they would change their minds in favor of Trump/Republicans.  The Senate presents what is certainly a more complex and challenging puzzle. I believe Cory Gardner is all but guaranteed to lose his seat. Likewise I believe there is a better than 75% chance Martha McSally loses her seat in Ariz. especially if Mark Kelly is her opponent. I believe there is also a more than likely probability (around 65%) chance that Susan Collins loses her seat as well. I believe Doug Jones will lose his seat to a Republican in Alabama in 2020 (88% chance of Republican win) leaving Democrats within just one seat of control (if Biden wins election as I believe he will). 
I believe Steve Bullock, if he gets the Democratic nomination in MT, has a strong chance of taking Steve Daines seat (around 66%) and that, depending upon the candidates selected by the parties, Democrats have a reasonable chance to pick up Pat Roberts seat in Kansas (likelihood of goes up significantly if Kris Kobach wins Republican nomination.  The cumulative effect of all of this is that Democrats have the potential to pick up the senate but are unlikely to overcome deep generational Republican strengths in states like Kansas, Iowa or Georgia. Democrats will also remain vulnerable in states like New Mexico and Michigan.

The most likely independent scenario seems to be maintaining the status quo. However, I think it's more likely that one party or the other has a massive windfall (30+25=55%). I give the democrats the edge in that because the incumbent presidential candidate is probably going to activate democratic base in a way that hasn't been seen in a decade or longer. That said i think the senate will swing to the same party of whoever wins the presidency.

First, I just assume Democrats will hold the House.  Last Tuesday's vote in Wisconsin seems like a pretty good harbinger of how fired up Dems are. For the Senate, in the worst case -- Trump wins, Doug Jones (D) loses in Alabama -- Democrats need a net gain of five seats to win it. * In Arizona, Mark Kelly is trouncing Martha McSally in fundraising, as well as in recent polling.  McSally is among the top 10 Senators with disapproval ratings by constituents.  Cook rates it a toss up, Sabato leaning Blue. * In Colorado, John Hickenlooper (D) is a popular former governor, and Cory Gardner (R) is among the top 10 Senators with highest disapproval ratings among constituents.  Gardner currently has more money, but Hickenlooper is rapidly closing the gap. Cook rates it a toss up, Sabato leaning Blue. * In Maine, Susan Collins has THE highest disapproval rating of all Senators among constituents.  Sara Gideon (D) is polling neck-and-neck with her, and has actually raised more than Collins.  Plus, there is a $4+ million "Defeat Collins" fund waiting for Gideon when she wins the Maine primary.  Both Cook and Sabato rate it a toss up. * In North Carolina, Cal Cunningham (D) is an extremely competitive candidate -- veteran, moderate -- and incumbent Thom Tillis (R) is a first-term Senator.  North Carolina has been trending purple: it has a Dem governor, and it went for Obama.  Cunningham in trailing Tillis just a bit in fundraising, but both Cook and Sabato rate it a toss up. *  In Montana, term-limited Governor Steve Bullock (D) has thrown his hat in the ring, and raised over $3 million almost immediately.  His opponent, Steve Daines, is a first-term Senator.  Both Cook and Sabato rate it Lean Red, but that was from Likely Red before Bullock entered the race.  * In Iowa Joni Ernst is having some problems, and Cook and Sabato changed it from Likely Red to Lean Red. * In Kansas former Republican/now Democrat Barbara Bollier (D) is beating all GOP contenders in terms of fundraising. Although both Cook and Sabato rate it Likely Red, if Tea Party darling Kris Kolbach (R) wins the GOP primary, this could very conceivably go Blue. * Finally, in Kentucky Mitch McConnell seems to be having a real fight on his hands with Amy McGrath (D). She has raised more than him, and was recently polling even with him.  Kentucky has a Democratic Governor, and McConnell only trails Susan Collins in terms of disapproval among constituents.  Although it might be a long shot, McConnell has already been forced to take around $10 million from a Senate PAC to help his campaign in Kentucky.  That's $10 million that cannot help Joni Ernst, Susan Collins, Thom Tillis, or Steve Daines. And although the smart money is on Doug Jones (D) losing Alabama this time, he's raised over $8 million, and his two competitors have barely raised $1 million between them.

1) We start with the probability that the Democrats retain the house. This probability is subject to a lot of change since it is most directly tied to the democrat's popularity on the generic ballot. Currently, democrats lead republicans on the generic ballot by 7.7 points per 538 (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-generic-ballot-polls/). Then we look to structural conditions: the likelihood of a recession (80%), the increased prevalence of Corona which, as the incumbents, Republicans will have to answer for. There are still some unknowns, how the economy will respond to Corona and how Corona will affect voting in November, but currently, most indicators point to democrats retaining the house. Particularly because their wave was due to suburban districts shifting from the Republican party a trend based on Trump and unlikely to be reversed. (85% Democrats hold the house)  2) Then we move to the probability that the Republicans retain the senate. Currently, they have a 3 seat lead which they need to hold onto. Additionally, Senator Doug Jones in Alabama is incredibly vulnerable as his state has a pronounced republican lean. While he has comparable approval ratings in Alabama to the Republican Senator (https://morningconsult.com/senator-rankings/), the fact that the election is in a presidential year will subject his race to turn out for Trump in Alabama. Democrats agree and are not investing in that race as of right now (https://www.politico.com/newsletters/morning-score/2020/03/24/senate-leadership-fund-announces-initial-fall-advertising-spend-786338). So it is fair to say the Democrats have to win 4 seats. However, there are only 4 seats in the toss-up column: Maine (Susan Collins), Colorado (Corey Gardner), North Caroline (Tills) and Arizona (Martha McSalley). Given statewide election results in 2018 and the newfound democratic tilt of Maine and Colorado, it is easy to imagine these states going into the Democratic column. Arizona is a swing state this year and will likely go the way of the presidential election but democrats are fielding a strong candidate (Mark Kelly) and he is up against Martha McSalley who lost in 2018, but barely. Democrats will need one more pick-up in North Carolina where they won the governorship in 2016 but lost on statewide ballots in 2018 by about 2 points. The electoral layout favors the republicans holding the Senate however democrats are only about 3 points on the generic ballot away from having a 50-50 shot to take the institution and the likely recession might put us over. There is still ambiguity over how Corona will affect voting but that is less of a concern because Maine, Colorado, and North Carolina have democratic governors who I assume will fight for their partisans to vote  (59% the Republicans hold the Senate).

With a 53-to-47 margin, more must go right for the Democrats than for the Republicans. Warren Buffett once said, "I don't look to jump over 7-foot bars: I look around for 1-foot bars that I can step over". It is not that Democrats cannot win the Senate -I assume they will maintain control of the House-, but that they have to jump over a 7-foot bar to do so and the Republicans have the easier task of jumping over a 1-foot bar. To take control, Democrats need a net gain of 4 seats or 3 seats plus the vice-president's tie-breaking vote. Added to this difficulty, the Senate electoral map does not favour the Democrats: the seats up for grabs already lean-Republican, so a conservative estimate would assume that the Republicans do enough to keep control. It's not a slam dunk: the Republicans are spread wide, defending 23 of the 35 seats on the ballot, so in terms of who has a chance to flip a seat, the Democrats are more likely. Election forecasters Inside Elections, Sabato’s Crystal Ball and The Cook Political Report currently rate Democrats’ opportunities to pick up seats more favorably than Republicans’. Again, Republicans have a margin of error.  2016 showed that Senate elections have become about national issues: every state in the Senate race backed the same party for president and Senate for the first time ever. So, a lot of this will hang on Biden's ability to compete widely.  Looking at Senate race rankings (https://cookpolitical.com/ratings/senate-race-ratings, http://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/2020-senate/, https://insideelections.com/ratings/senate), senators Martha McSally (R-AZ), Susan Collins (R-ME), Cory Gardner (R-CO), Thom Tillis (R-NC), and Joni Ernst (R-IA) are in toss-up races, with Doug Jones (D-AL) in a race leaning Republican. Republicans have a lot to do, but again, they have plenty of room to fail.
